awd_abstract_narration:
NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project will support 16 highly qualified, low income biology and chemistry majors.  Academic and social support activities for the scholars includes (a) cohort-based learning communities, (b) peer and faculty mentoring, and (c) early and consistent research experiences via course-based research and other more traditional student faculty collaborations.  The project is anchored in Cabrini College's Justice Matters core curriculum, which has been recognized nationally for its innovative approach to integrating civic and social responsibility into student learning.  Through it scholars will be provided with opportunities for meaningful community engagement related to their STEM major.  This effort will address the national need to increase the number of American STEM majors while at the same time developing future scientists with a strong social justice ethos and commitment to serving the community, both locally and nationally.

This ambitious plan is based on the hypothesis that engaging the S-STEM scholars in STEM learning and career exposure through a framework of social justice will help to secure their retention to graduation and placement in graduate or professional positions in STEM fields.  The Justice Matters curriculum will be designed to include a sequence of developmentally linked, writing intensive courses taken each year that will help students to develop knowledge, critical thinking, values, and skills that can benefit others and link issues of social justice, ethical decision making, and civic engagement to science-based topics.  Undergraduate research, career preparation activities, and service projects will also bridge science to themes related to social responsibility.  All courses, program elements, recruitment strategies, and support services created or modified for the purpose of this project will be carefully evaluated in terms of their impact on student recruitment, learning, retention to graduation, and career/higher education placement. This project will investigate how impactful a social justice curriculum is on students' STEM career/higher education choices, and it will also examine the way in which a mentoring program with specifically defined activities contributes to student success.  Faculty and students will share results from the project at Faculty Development Workshops and Cabrini's annual Art and Research Symposium.  Manuscripts will be submitted for publication and results will be presented at regional and national conferences.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the Science Scholars for Social Justice (SSSJ) program at Cabrini University was to attract and retain academically talented science majors with unmet financial need, and provide them with the resources and support to succeed during their time at Cabrini, and in their scientific field of choice after graduation. The program also sought to evaluate the effectiveness of a set of academic and social interventions, including enhanced onboarding, mindset training, faculty and peer mentoring, academic workshops, service opportunities, and career guidance.

Our program served 22 students in the Biology and Chemistry majors between 2016 and 2022. These students participated in multi-day on-campus onboarding programs before the start of their Freshman and Sophomore years, designed to jump-start their academic skills and research interests, while allowing them to bond with the SSSJ faculty, their peer mentors, and each other. Throughout the academic year, the students participated in a series of workshops which alternated between academic skills-building, the planning and implementation of service learning projects, and career talks by scientists in a variety of fields and positions. In addition, the students took a series of social justice focused courses together as a cohort.

During their time at Cabrini, the two cohorts of SSSJ scholars developed and implemented meaningful community service projects. One cohort worked researched best practices at community and university food pantries, and worked to improve Cabrini’s on-campus food pantry. They developed healthy recipes using food pantry staples, and created online cooking demonstration videos to present these recipes. The other cohort provided peer tutoring to fellow Cabrini science students, and developed and disseminated science activity packets for preschool and early elementary school children. In addition, both cohorts worked on a project in which they collected soil samples from the playgrounds of childcare and community centers to be tested for lead, then presented results and recommendations to their community partners in order to help them better protect kids from lead exposure.

Nearly all of the SSSJ scholars carried out independent research during their time at Cabrini, either with faculty on campus or at outside institutions. These students presented their work at a variety of regional and national conferences, including the Pennsylvania Academy of Science, the National Council on Undergraduate Research, and the American Chemical Society.

Although 3 of the 22 SSSJ scholars ultimately transferred to other institutions, the remaining 19 all graduated within 4 years, greatly exceeding the retention and graduation rates of science majors outside the SSSJ program. In addition, after graduation, SSSJ scholars entered jobs within their chosen science field, or scientific graduate or professional programs, at a higher rate than other science majors within the university.

In focus group discussions, the SSSJ students indicated that the program’s opportunities to bond with faculty and other students, as well as the additional support and mentoring, improved their undergraduate experience. Students particularly highlighted the social justice framework and the service learning projects as important contributors to their scientific education. These student impressions, as well as the numerical outcomes described above, all suggest that the interventions in the Science Scholars for Social Justice program were successful.

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2022
Modified by: Caroline B Nielsen
